Láinez spent the entire 2004–05 recovering from knee surgery, and ultimately retired from football in May 2005, at only 28.
Láinez returned to his lifetime club Zaragoza on 9 October 2014, being appointed manager of the reserves.

He was instrumental in the Aragonese club's immediate promotion, and subsequently helped it finish in a comfortable 12th place, also conquering the Copa del Rey after an extra time win against Real Madrid.
After his return to Zaragoza, Láinez had to wait until the 2001–02 campaign to become first-choice, but his team would again be relegated.

== Club career ==
A Real Zaragoza youth graduate, Zaragoza-born Láinez made his professional debut with its B-side, but struggled initially to find a first-team place.
He subsequently became a sports commentator for local TV channels.
On 19 March 2017 he replaced Raül Agné at the helm of the first team, who now competed in Segunda División.

He has also stood out for his penalty–stopping abilities throughout his career; with 19 stops in 364 appearances since 2009, he has parried the joint–third–most penalties in Serie A history, behind only Gianluca Pagliuca and Samir Handanović, with 24 stops each.
The following season, he was loaned to Serie B side Rimini.
Then he was selected by head coach Pierluigi Casiraghi in the squad for the 2007 U-21 Championship as the third choice goalkeeper.

== International career ==
Consigli made his debut with the Italy U21 squad on 15 August 2006, in a friendly match against Croatia.
To gain some first team experience, the young goalkeeper was loaned out to Serie C1 side Sambenedettese in the 2006–07 season.
His role model as a goalkeeper is Gianluigi Buffon.

== Club career ==
Born in Cormano, Consigli is a youth product of Atalanta.
He took up cycling at the age of 16, receiving his first bike from his half-brother, racing cyclist Jeremy Hunt.

She redshirted the next season due to injuring her patella during the home opener.

== Coaching career ==
Lappe began her coaching career back in Iowa as an assistant at Drake University, a position she held from 2003 to 2006.

== Career ==

Careerwise, she averaged 10.3 points per game and was a second team All-Big East Conference selection for the 2005–06 season, as well as, a second team All-Conference USA selection for the 2003–04 and 2004–05 seasons.

=== Return to light flyweight ===
Miyazaki made his light flyweight debut against Teeraphong Utaida on 31 December 2013.
Miyazaki retained the belt by a fifth-round technical knockout.
His two-fight win streak was snapped by Azael Villar, who stopped him by technical knockout in the first round.

Miyazaki amassed a 9–0–2 record before being booked to face the #9 ranked WBC light flyweight contender Munetsugu Kayo for the Japanese light-flyweight title on 12 October 2009.

==== Miyazaki vs. Velarde ====
Miyazaki made his first minimumweight title defense against Carlos Velarde on 8 May 2013, once against on the Kazuto Ioka undercard and once again at the Osaka Prefectural Gymnasium in Osaka, Japan.

==== Miyazaki vs. Silvestre ====
Miyazaki made his second WBA world title defense against the WBA interim minimumweight champion Jesús Silvestre on 11 September 2013.
Miyazaki made his third title defense with a fourth-round knockout of Jerson Mancio on 2 October 2011.
He captured his second professional title by technical knockout, as he stopped Iezumi at the 2:41 minute mark of the eighth round.
He retained the title by majority decision, with two judges scoring the fight 115–114 and 115–113 in his favor, while the third judge scored the fight an even 114–114.
The fight was ruled a draw by technical decision early in the fourth round.
The owner of Miyazaki's gym furthermore announced he would award his fighter a ¥1,000,000 bonus, should he win by stoppage.
Miyazaki next faced Takumi Sakae in a flyweight bout on 29 April 2022.
He suffered his first professional loss, as Utaida knocked him out at the 2:22 minute mark of the third round.
Miyazaki made his second title defense against Donny Mabao on 12 June 2011.

In many areas, he foresaw the current debate on the critical Marxian language of class, bourgeoisie, and hegemony finds little echo in contemporary political science, where its positivism requires researchers to focus on putative measurable and objective entities.

In his later works, Poulantzas analysed the role of what he termed the "new petty bourgeoisie" in both consolidating the ruling classes hegemony and undermining the proletariat's ability to organise itself.

By occupying a contradictory class position—that is to say, by identifying with its de facto oppressor—this fraction of the working class throws its lot in with the bourgeois whose fate it (wrongly) believes it shares.

The fragmentation (some would argue the demise) of the class system is, for Poulantzas, a defining characteristic of late capitalism, and any politically useful analysis must tackle this new constellation of interests and power.

On 5 August 2017, Lucas made his Bath debut during their 3–2 away defeat to newly promoted side Bognor Regis Town, replacing Marvin Morgan in the 63rd minute.
On 5 September, Rovers agreed to extend Lucas' loan by two months.
After a couple of successful loan spells, Bristol Rovers called Lucas back.
On 15 June 2018, it was announced that Lucas would return to Weston-super-Mare on a one-year deal.
On 16 December 2017, Lucas made his Brackley debut during their FA Trophy tie against Braintree Town, featuring for 77 minutes in the 0–0 draw.
On 22 June 2022, after struggling with injury during the 2021–22 campaign, Lucas agreed to join Worcester Raiders.
On 25 August, Lucas scored his second goal for Weston, which earned his team a 1–0 victory over Staines Town.
Lucas came on as a late substitute against Plymouth Argyle replacing Jermaine Easter.

== Club career ==
On 21 April, Lucas made his professional debut against Rochdale towards the end of the season.
After an unsuccessful loan back at Boreham Wood, Lucas joined fellow National League side Woking on loan until the end of the campaign.
His first goal for the Seagulls came in a 3–2 victory over Farnborough on 11 August.
On 23 May 2017, Lucas joined National League South side Bath City on a one-year deal.
On 7 August, Lucas signed for new National League side Boreham Wood.
He came off the bench in the 79th minute, replacing Tom Parkes.
Just under a month later, he scored his first goal for Bath during their 1–1 home draw with Welling United, netting their equaliser after Harry Phipps had given the visitors the lead.
On 25 March 2017, Lucas scored his first goal for Woking in their 4–2 home defeat against Maidstone United.
Following a spell at Evesham United, whilst on loan from Halesowen Town, Lucas returned to The Robins on a permanent basis ahead of the 2020–21 campaign.
On 18 March 2017, Lucas made his Woking debut in their 2–1 away defeat against Gateshead, featuring for 58 minutes before being replaced Ben Morris.

== Early life and career ==

Ardzinba, who was a charismatic but excitable figure popular among the Abkhaz, was believed by Georgians to have helped to instigate the violence of July 1989.
In mid-1991, he negotiated and accepted the Georgian concession on the reform of the electoral law that granted the Abkhaz wide over-representation in the Supreme Soviet.
Vladislav Ardzinba (Abkhaz: Владислав Арӡынба, Georgian: ვლადისლავ არძინბა; 14 May 1945 – 4 March 2010) was the first de facto President of Abkhazia.
He once stated that independence from Georgia is not negotiable, and he has tried to align the state with Russia, whose political and economic support was essential to the republic.

He then worked for eighteen years in Moscow specialising in ancient Middle Eastern civilizations under Yevgeniy Primakov, then head of the Institute of Oriental Studies in Moscow, and later Russian foreign and Prime Minister.
However, although the Abkhaz Constitution allows for impeachment, the process would likely have not been completed before the end of his term, so no serious steps were taken to bring it about.
He won the first direct polls on 3 October 1999, without an opponent and was re-elected as president of Abkhazia.

Ardzinba managed to consolidate his power relatively quickly and reneged on pre-election promises to increase the representation of Georgians in Abkhazia's autonomous structures; since then, Ardzinba tried to rule Abkhazia relatively single-handedly, but avoided, for the time being, overt conflict with the central authorities in Tbilisi.

Despite increasing calls from the opposition (particularly the Amtsakhara movement) for him to resign he had stated that he would finish his term, which was supposed to end in October 2004, but in fact did not end until 12 February 2005, due to disputes over the election of his successor.
He had been escorted there the previous week.

However, Ardzinba created the Abkhazian National Guard that was mono-ethnically Abkhaz, and initiated a practice of replacing ethnic Georgians in leading positions with Abkhaz.

He then returned to Sukhumi and he served there as the director of the Abkhazian Institute of Language, Literature and History from 1987 until 1989, when he was elected a Deputy to the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union from Gudauta.
As the Georgian-Abkhaz tensions rose, Ardzinba's rhetoric mounted, as he claimed in late July 1992 that "Abkhazia is strong enough to fight Georgia.
He installed an autocratic regime and remained politically untouchable until his health seriously deteriorated in 2003.

== Club career ==

He enjoyed a successful three-season spell with Milan, winning the 1987–88 Serie A title, the 1988 Supercoppa Italiana, consecutive European Cups (1988–89 and 1989–90), as well as the 1989 Intercontinental Cup, and the 1989 European Super Cup, with his final appearance coming in Milan's 1–0 victory over Benfica in the 1990 European Cup Final on 23 May; in total he made 115 appearances for the club between 1987 and 1990, scoring 7 goals, all of which came in his 77 Serie A appearances with the club.

However, he stood out in particular for his stamina, tenacity, intelligence, attacking movement off the ball, and defensive work-rate, as well as his ball-winning abilities, which made him a key player in Sacchi's legendary Milan side of the late 80s, and which allowed him to contribute at both ends of the pitch.

== Biography ==
Born of the mightiest and highest resident family of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania (as well as a blood descendant of King Casimir IV of Poland, and Kęstutis and Vytautas, monarchs of Lithuania), Radziwiłł was the owner of Biržai, Dubingiai, Słuck, and Kopyta, the great Standard-bearer of Lithuania since 1638, the Master of the Stables of Lithuania since 1648, and the Starost of Bar.
In the Battle of Prostki on 8 October 1656, Bogusław's forces were decimated by the Commonwealth forces under Hetman Wincenty Korwin Gosiewski.

Together with his cousin Janusz Radziwiłł in 1654 during The Deluge, or Swedish invasion of Poland, Bogusław Radziwiłł began negotiations with King Charles X Gustav of Sweden aimed at breaking the Commonwealth and the Polish–Lithuanian union.
He was of the Radziwiłł magnate family.
He was a descendant of the famous knight, Zawisza the Black.

The former died at Tykocin Castle besieged by forces loyal to the Commonwealth, while Bogusław retreated with his forces to Prussia, where he supported Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg, against the Polish king.
Boguslaw married Anna Maria Radziwiłł, the only daughter of his relative and collaborator, the late prince Janusz.
In turn, this couple had only one surviving child, a daughter, Ludwika Karolina Radziwiłł.
Bogusław Radziwiłł (Lithuanian: Boguslavas Radvila; 3 May 1620 – 31 December 1669) was a Polish princely magnate and a member of the Polish-Lithuanian szlachta, or nobility.

In Poland it is believed that Bogusław's and Janusz's only lasting achievement was to tarnish the Radziwiłł family name for years to come with their treason, eclipsing the deeds of other Radziwiłłs like Michał Kazimierz Radziwiłł, who fought for the Crown and the Commonwealth against the Swedes.
The Swedish defeat and eventual retreat from the territories of the Commonwealth abruptly ended the plans of Janusz and Bogusław.
He was the last Calvinist male member of his family.

== Education and career ==

== Federal judicial service ==

Max (Mordechai) Farbmann (1 April 1886 – 20 April 1950) was a Lithuanian Jewish sculptor who achieved prominence in Europe, particularly Vienna, Austria, during the early 20th century.

== Biography ==
Max (Mordechai) Farbmann was born in 1886 in Salakas (Solok) in present-day Lithuania, and moved to Vienna at the age of 20 to study sculpture.
Farbmann was a versatile sculptor who worked in multiple mediums, including bronze, wood, stone, and ivory.
There, he earned a reputation, leading the Vienna Arts Academy to purchase one of his works – a noted achievement for a Jewish artist.

Among his works were commissioned sculpted busts of prominent European figures, including many leading statesmen, as well as the Lithuanian Independence Monument, which was erected in his hometown of Solok in 1930.
Nevertheless, Farbmann continued to create sculptures, focusing more on Jewish themes in his later career.

Kramer was born in Schneidemühl (Province of Posen) (today Piła, Poland), where he grew up.
After World War II Kramer returned to the Soviet Occupation Zone of Germany and joined the Socialist Unity Party of Germany (SED) in 1946.
In 1937 he passed a course in "Military Tactics" at the Red Army's military school at Tambov and fought as a member of the XI.
In 1939 he was interned in a French camp at Saint-Cyprien, Pyrénées-Orientales  and returned to the Soviet Union, where he worked for the German desk of Radio Moscow.
In 1930-32 Kramer worked as a workmaster for the Reichsbahn administration of Berlin.
In 1932 Kramer emigrated to the Soviet Union and worked at the "Central Research Institute of Transportation" in Moscow.

Julio Estuardo Girón Rafael (born March 2, 1970) is a retired Guatemalan football midfielder.

== International career ==
Girón made his debut for Guatemala in a June 1992 friendly match against Nicaragua and played in three different World Cup qualification campaigns.
He earned 82 caps, in which he never scored a goal.

== Family ==
Welles married three times.

== Early life and education ==
Welles was born on April 20, 1907, in Cincinnati, Ohio, the son of the Reverend Samuel Gardner Welles and Mabel De Geer.

== Bishop ==
On December 6, 1949, Welles was elected as the forth Bishop of West Missouri and was consecrated on April 19, 1950, in Grace and Holy Trinity Cathedral by Presiding Bishop Henry Knox Sherrill.
Between 1973 and 1990, he served as Assistant Bishop in Maine.
He was president of the board directors at Saint Luke's Hospital in Kansas City, Missouri, between 1950 and 1969, and then chairman of the Board from 1969 until 1972.
He then was elected dean of All Saints Cathedral in Albany and in 1940 became rector of Christ Church in Alexandria, Virginia.
He retired as Bishop of West Missouri in 1972.
He served as rector of Trinity Church in Woodbridge, New Jersey, between 1931 and 1934.
He was educated at Kent School and later studied at Princeton University from where he graduated with a Bachelor of Arts in 1928.
He then undertook studies at the University of Oxford from where he earned a Bachelor of Arts in 1930, and a Master of Arts in 1934.
During his episcopacy the number of communicants in his diocese increased, and 12 new congregations were created.
He was also chaplain at St Mark's School in Southborough, Massachusetts, from 1934 until 1936.
His grandfather was the Bishop of Milwaukee Edward R. Welles.
== References ==
He died quietly in his sleep on April 15, 1991, at his home in Kansas City, Missouri.
He also attended the General Theological Seminary from where he graduated with a Bachelor of Sacred Theology in 1932.

== Ordained Ministry ==
Welles was ordained deacon in April 1931 priest in October 1931 by the Bishop of New Jersey Paul Matthews.

== Career ==
Ladd's professional career in Hollywood began in 1957 with a supporting role in a film starring his father titled The Big Land.
The film was quite successful, and he was subsequently asked to join his half-brother Alan Ladd Jr in forming Pathe Films in 1988.
His mother was Sue Carol, Alan Ladd's second wife, who was an actress and talent agent.
